caption_original: On July , , Victoria Tschirhart will be taking over our Instagram account to show us what it’s like to be a geophysicist doing summer fieldwork. She will be showing us everything from what her team is working on to how scientists travel while in remote locations. Stay tuned!

caption_original: When we’re out in the field, we have to get up early. There’s always quite a bit of work to do in the morning, and we need to make sure to eat a big, healthy breakfast to get us through the day!

caption_original: This is Charlene, everyone’s favourite summer student! Charlene is starting an M.Sc. degree in geology this fall, so this eedition will give her some great hands-on eerience in remote settings while learning more about economic geology. Charlene will be taking detailed measurements on drill core samples, assisting with digital data management, helping manage the camp and contributing ideas to the deposit models.

caption_original: When we get to the location, it’s straight to work — everyone has their targets. Each one of us seeks to collect data to solve the research questions we formulated before leaving for the field.

caption_original: Today, we will be hiking through the bush to get some drill cores — samples of a natural material previously removed using a cylinder drill. While at the core storage area, we take samples and measurements from the drill core to get information about the subsurface. Sometimes the drill core is only accessible by overgrown roads, so it can be quite the journey tracking it down!
caption_cleaned: Today hiking bush get drill cores samples natural material previously removed using cylinder drill nWhile core storage area take samples measurements drill core get information subsurface nSometimes drill core accessible overgrown roads quite journey tracking Fieldwork SummerFieldwork Hiking NRCanSci

caption_original: Hi everyone, and welcome to my summer home! It’s geophysicist Vicki Tschirhart here! My field site is located in the Patterson Lake corridor, southwestern Athabasca Basin, a region known for its uranium deposits. Our multidisciplinary field party includes geochemists, geochronologists, geophysicists and geologists, eerts who have the collective goal of understanding how and why these deposits formed.
caption_cleaned: Hi everyone welcome summer home geophysicist Vicki Tschirhart nMy field site located Patterson Lake corridor southwestern Athabasca Basin region known uranium deposits nOur multidisciplinary field party includes geochemists geochronologists geophysicists geologists experts collective goal understanding deposits formed Fieldwork SummerFieldwork NRCanSci GeoScience Exploration cribs homesweethome

caption_original: We may be done in the field for the day, but we need to go over the data collected, discuss our findings and plan our targets for tomorrow. Fieldwork often involves very long work days — but it’s worth it for the science.
caption_cleaned: may done field day need go data collected discuss findings plan targets tomorrow Fieldwork often involves long work days worth science ItsWorthItForTheExercise AndNature Fieldwork

caption_original: Kathryn Bethune is a Professor of Geology at the University of Regina. She and her Ph.D. student, Dillon Johnstone, are investigating the regional setting and related structural controls of uranium deposits in the area. The primary aim is to create a fuller -D and -D picture of the major structural features and their relationship to the uranium deposits, as well as getting a fuller understanding of the sequence and timing of structures.
caption_cleaned: Kathryn Bethune Professor Geology University Regina Ph student Dillon Johnstone investigating regional setting related structural controls uranium deposits area nThe primary aim create fuller picture major structural features relationship uranium deposits well getting fuller understanding sequence timing structures WomenInScience Geology uranium Canada

caption_original: Welcome to “Come dine with me Athabasca,” where Canada’s best and brightest government scientists battle it out to become ultimate camp chef! Because we are in a smaller camp, we cook our own food and each member is responsible for at least one communal dinner. This can often lead to some friendly competition as to who’s the best cook.
caption_cleaned: Welcome Come dine Athabasca best brightest government scientists battle become ultimate camp chef nBecause smaller camp cook food member responsible least one communal dinner often lead friendly competition best cook ItsDefinitelyVicki ComeDineWithMe CampMeals Fieldwork

caption_original: Meet Jeremy! My colleague Jeremy Powell is interested in the low-temperature history of southern Athabasca. He’s combing the drill core for fractures and faults, using many different techniques to understand when these structures were active. Dating the movement of these structures and the timing of hydrothermal fluids that circulated through them will help us learn how and when these uranium deposits formed.
caption_cleaned: Meet Jeremy nMy colleague Jeremy Powell interested low temperature history southern Athabasca combing drill core fractures faults using many different techniques understand structures active nDating movement structures timing hydrothermal fluids circulated help us learn uranium deposits formed Faults geochron RockClock NotMyFault fieldwork

caption_original: Meet Eric Potter, a fellow research scientist at the GSC. Eric studies how and why these uranium deposits formed. For this project, Eric is looking for ancient chemical fingerprints of fluids that formed these deposits. This research is attempting to create a way of identifying faults that channeled the uranium-bearing fluids to the site of the deposit and addressing questions on how the deposits form.
caption_cleaned: Meet Eric Potter fellow research scientist GSC Eric studies uranium deposits formed nFor project Eric looking ancient chemical fingerprints fluids formed deposits research attempting create way identifying faults channeled uranium bearing fluids site deposit addressing questions deposits form fieldwork uranium exploration
